Indications and doses

Urinary-tract infections, Respiratory tract infections,

By mouth

  • For adults
    200 mg twice daily.
  • For children 4–5 weeks
    4 mg/kg twice daily (max. per dose 200 mg).
  • For children 6 weeks–5 months
    4 mg/kg twice daily (max. per dose 200 mg), alternatively 25 mg twice daily.
  • For children 6 months–5 years
    4 mg/kg twice daily (max. per dose 200 mg), alternatively 50 mg twice daily.
  • For children 6–11 years
    4 mg/kg twice daily (max. per dose 200 mg), alternatively 100 mg twice daily.
  • For children 12–17 years
    200 mg twice daily.

Prophylaxis of urinary-tract infection (considered for recurrent infection, significant urinary-tract anomalies, or significant kidney damage),

By mouth

  • For adults
    100 mg once daily, dose to be taken at night.
  • For children 4–5 weeks
    2 mg/kg once daily (max. per dose 100 mg), dose to be taken at night.
  • For children 6 weeks–5 months
    2 mg/kg once daily (max. per dose 100 mg), dose to be taken at night, alternatively 12.5 mg once daily, dose to be taken at night.
  • For children 6 months–5 years
    2 mg/kg once daily (max. per dose 100 mg), dose to be taken at night, alternatively 25 mg once daily, dose to be taken at night.
  • For children 6–11 years
    2 mg/kg once daily (max. per dose 100 mg), dose to be taken at night, alternatively 50 mg once daily, dose to be taken at night.
  • For children 12–17 years
    100 mg once daily, dose to be taken at night.

Treatment of mild to moderate Pneumocystis jirovecii ( Pneumocystis carinii ) pneumonia in patients who cannot tolerate co-trimoxazole (in combination with dapsone),

By mouth

  • For adults
    5 mg/kg every 6–8 hours.
  • For children
    5 mg/kg every 6–8 hours.

Acne resistant to other antibacterials,

By mouth

  • For adults
    300 mg twice daily.

Prostatitis,

By mouth

  • For adults
    (consult product literature).

Shigellosis, Invasive salmonella infection,

By mouth

  • For adults
    (consult product literature).

Advice when patient is pregnant

Teratogenic risk in first trimester (folate antagonist); manufacturers advise avoid.

Advice regarding renal impairment

In adults

Use half normal dose after 3 days if eGFR 15–30 mL/minute/1.73 m2.

Use half normal dose if eGFR less than 15 mL/minute/1.73 m2.

In children

Use half normal dose after 3 days if estimated glomerular filtration rate 15–30 mL/minute/1.73 m2.

Use half normal dose if estimated glomerular filtration rate less than 15 mL/minute/1.73 m2.

Contra indications

  • Blood dyscrasias

Known side effects

General side effects

rare: Allergic reactions, anaphylaxis, angioedema, erythema multiforme, photosensitivity, toxic epidermal necrolysis,

notKnown: Aseptic meningitis, depression of haematopoiesis, gastro-intestinal disturbances, hyperkalaemia, nausea, pruritus, rashes, uveitis in adults, vomiting,

Trimethoprim has side-effects similar to co-trimoxazole but they are less severe and occur less frequently.

Advice for patients and carers

Blood disorders

On long-term treatment, patients and their carers should be told how to recognise signs of blood disorders and advised to seek immediate medical attention if symptoms such as fever, sore throat, rash, mouth ulcers, purpura, bruising or bleeding develop.

In children

Medicines for Children leaflet: Trimethoprim for bacterial infections

www.medicinesforchildren.org.uk/trimethoprim-for-bacterial-infections

Cautions regarding administration

  • : Elderly in adults
  • Acute porphyrias
  • : neonates (specialist supervision required) in neonates
  • predisposition to folate deficiency

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

Manufacturer recommends blood counts on long-term therapy (but evidence of practical value unsatisfactory).

Unlicensed use

In children

Not licensed for use in children under 6 weeks.

In adults

Not licensed for treatment of acne resistant to other antibacterials.

Not licensed for treatment of pneumocystis pneumonia.

Prepared medicinal forms of TRIMETHOPRIM

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: oral solution, oral suspension,
